attributes.title: Are categorization effects enhanced by meaningful vs. arbitrary labels in a breathing paradigm?
attributes.description:
Precise monitoring of body sensations ("interoceptive accuracy", Khalsa et al., 2018) is essential to maintain homeostasis and can even be lifesaving, e.g. in asthma. Previous research showed that basal perceptual processes such as stimulus organization are at work in interoception: When comparing somatic stimuli in a breathing paradigm, type of categorization (arbitrary vs. continuous categorical organization) influenced magnitude estimations as well as breathing behavior in healthy participants (Petersen, Schroijen, Mölders, Zenker, & Van den Bergh, 2014). Specifically, different breathing resistance loads were perceived as more similar within than between categories. In addition, self-reported number and frequency of somatic symptoms were associated with an overestimation of stimulus intensities at category borders (Petersen, Van Staeyen, Vogele, von Leupoldt, & Van den Bergh, 2015). Next to arbitrary categories, previous research showed that interoceptive perceptions are also influenced by contextual information. For example, Bogaerts et al. (2008) found lower interoceptive accuracy of breathing sensations in high symptom reporters in a symptom-related, but not in a neutral context. 

The predictive coding theory of symptom perception assumes that symptom predictions influence body perception (Van den Bergh, Witthöft, Petersen, & Brown, 2017). Arbitrary and continual categories might influence such predictions and thereby change perceptions. This in turn may help explain the development and maintenance of somatic symptom disorders. 

The present study was designed to 1) replicate findings of a basic categorization effects on the classification of breathing sensations (Petersen et al., 2014), 2) examine whether meaningful labels (categories “sensations” and “symptoms”) produce stronger categorization effects than arbitrary labels (categories “A” and “B”), and 3) relate potential categorization effects to psychopathological measures such as symptom reporting and illness anxiety.

summary.value: For the sake of better readability the pre-registration is attached in a pdf-file.

registration_responses.summary: For the sake of better readability the pre-registration is attached in a pdf-file.

q1.value: Examination of domain restriction effects on the interpretation of plural definite descriptions

q3.value:
Developmental literature suggests that children often exhibit the non-maximal interpretation of plural definite descriptions (PDDs). The cause of such an interpretation has been attributed to the initial association of PDDs with plurality but not maximality (Karmiloff-Smith 1979), and the lack of mapping of linguistic structure to the associated concepts (Caponigro et al. 2012). The acquisition trajectory to the maximal interpretation that adults exhibit, however, is still poorly understood.

Another possible cause of non-maximal interpretation is children’s non-adult-like domain restriction (DR), which enables the existential readings of PDD. It is possible that, while children do assign maximal interpretations to PDDs, they appear to treat them existentially because they restrict the domain of reference to a subset of items. A recent study by Tieu et al. (2019) assumes that DR is linguistically mediated (i.e. interpreting “The hearts are blue” as “The hearts that are blue are blue”), and rejects this analysis on the ground that their subjects did not provide the non-maximal interpretation for PDDs in negative sentences.  

The current study attempts to examine the nature and the role of DR in more depth. We argue that it is still premature to conclude that DR is irrelevant to children’s non-maximal interpretation based on Tieu et al.’s findings. Unlike positive sentences, negative sentences mention the objects that would disable the non-maximal interpretation of PDDs; for instance, hearing “The hearts are not red” with an array of red and yellow hearts directs the subject’s attention to the red hearts, from which they could judge the sentence as false. Thus, children’s performance of interpreting negative PDDs in Tieu et al.’s study is likely to be confounded with the mention effect.

Furthermore, Schwartz (2012) argues that while the maximal interpretation is the default for PDDs, adult English speakers could also interpret PDDs non-maximally when a restricted domain is applied. Crucially, Schwartz’ definition of DR is guided by contextual information, which contrasts with the linguistically mediated DR assumed by Tieu et al. Hence, this study tests different approaches to DR that can result in the non-maximal interpretation of PDDs, and investigates whether they predict the pattern of interpretation of PDDs among adults and children.

q4.value:
We first ask whether children are sensitive to DR. We consider two possibilities regarding their non-maximal interpretation of PDDs: Either they are yet to develop the concept of maximality associated with PDDs, or they are aware of the maximality requirement of PDDs but their interpretation is more amenable to DR than in adults.

The former indicates that children’s interpretation of PDDs is on a par with that of indefinite plurals (e.g. “Some hearts are red.”). Alternatively, if the pattern of interpretation of definite and indefinite plurals differ, either linguistically and contextually mediated DR should be at play in making the non-maximal interpretation of PDDs possible.

The next question is concerned with the nature of DR. An important distinction between linguistically and contextually mediated DR is that the former does not require that maximality holds among associated objects, while the latter does, in an alternative domain that does not encompass all of the objects in the display.

Hence, if children are sensitive only to the linguistically mediated DR, they are likely to accept any situations where the existential readings of PDD are possible. If, on the other hand, their interpretation of PDDs is subject to contextual factors (just like adults are), the non-maximal interpretation should be readily induced in situations where the associated objects are visually contiguous.

Another question to be addressed in this study is how DR explains different patterns of interpretation of PDDs among adults and children. Given the hypothesis that children’s notion of maximality tied to PDDs is unstable, children should be more sensitive to contextual DR effects than adults. Therefore, manipulating the contextual information should affect children to a greater extent than adults. Furthermore, it is also likely that a difference is observed among children depending on age groups. The younger they are, the more vulnerable (or even absent) their notion of maximality is, and thus their interpretation of PDDs is comparable to that of indefinite plurals. As they age, however, the notion of maximality becomes stronger, but their interpretation of PDDs should still be non-adult-like as it is highly subject to the contextually-driven DR.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We have a within-subject design where each subject is exposed to trials with different sentence types and object types.

For each trial, the subject sees a group of objects in one of the four types: All target objects, mixed objects (with the target objects clustered together), mixed objects (with the target objects split), and no target object. The visual stimulus is accompanied by a sentence with either a universal quantifier (e.g. “All of the animals are lions”), an indefinite existential quantifier (e.g. “Some of the animals are lions”), or a PDD (“The animals are lions”). Sentences with universal and indefinite existential quantifiers are treated as controls, as adults and children have been shown to behave similarly in interpreting them.

The order of trials is pseudo-randomized, resulting in 2 experimental orders. Subjects are equally assigned to each order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will start collecting data from adult controls first, to test whether we replicate the contextual manipulation effect observed in Schwartz (2012) using child-friendly stimuli. Data collection from children is thus contingent on a successful replication of the contextual effect among adults, with our experimental paradigm or, if necessarily, with Schwartz’s original stimuli. 

Adult subjects will be recruited for the online pilot and the on-site experiment. The pilot will be conducted on Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT), a crowdsourcing platform where workers get compensated ($1.20) for completing the task. Adult subjects for the on-site experiment consist of University of California, San Diego undergraduate students participating for course credit. In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, we might keep using AMT for testing adults in lieu of on-site experiment.

Child participants will be typically developing native, fluent, English speaking children between the ages of 4;0 and 7;0. Participants will be recruited from databases of interested families, at sites throughout the community, through their preschools, or through other events in the greater San Diego area. In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, children may also be recruited and tested online.

We will first focus on recruiting child subjects from a restricted age range (4;6 to 6;6), as we predict that the effect of contextual manipulations on the interpretation of PDDs will be particularly prominent among children from this age range.
  
After getting enough subjects from the restricted age range, we will qualitatively examine the results from the oldest and youngest subjects. If the performance of the oldest subjects is almost adult-like, we will not collect data from subjects aged 6;6-7;0, as their performance is predicted to be almost adult-like as well and thus not particularly informative. Likewise, if the youngest subjects from the restricted age range exhibit no notion of maximality, subjects aged 4;0-4;6 are likely to perform similarly, and thus we will not collect data from them either. 

For adult subjects, because some of them will be tested online, we will use exclusion criteria to ensure data quality, following norms of online testing: American IP address, and self-reporting English as their only native language.

In addition, we will base exclusion on control trials (i.e. trials with some and all sentence types) where judgments should be unanimous. There are 8 such trials, and any participant who provides the incorrect answer for at least 6 of them will be excluded from analysis. For child subjects, we will not exclude any data unless they fail the training trials (see Section 17 for details) or they fail to complete the experiment.

q13.value:
The target sample size for children is N=80 post-exclusion, with approximately 20 for each age group (4, 5, 6, and 7-year-olds). We also aim for N=20 as the sample size of adult subjects.

If we decide to recruit children from only the restricted age range (as noted in Section 9.1.1.), the sample size will be N=40 post-exclusion, with approximately 20 for each age group (4;6-5;6, 5;7-6;6).

q15.value: We will stop collecting data once we reach our target sample size.

question.value:
Forced choice task: Subjects will be presented with two characters, and the experimenter will tell them that one character is very smart and “always says things that are just right,” and the other character “always says things that are silly or not true”. On each trial, subjects see the objects, hear a sentence starting with “Somebody says... (e.g. the animals are lions),” and they are asked which character has said the sentence. As a response, they choose between the smart and silly characters.

Crucially, which character subjects choose in the mixed object trials in response to a sentence with PDD will determine if they interpret PDDs maximally or non-maximally. Because the smart character should always produce a sentence that correctly captures the state of objects, choosing the character indicates that subjects have made the non-maximal interpretation of PDD. In contrast, if they prefer the maximal interpretation for PDDs, they should choose the silly character as the speaker in such trials.

Raw responses (choice between the blindfolded and seeing characters) will be coded as maximal (1) or non-maximal (0) for critical trials, and correct (1) or incorrect (0) for controls.
 
We will construct a binomial mixed effects regression model predicting binary responses (correct/maximal vs. incorrect/non-maximal) as a function of Sentence Type (all/some/PDD), Object Type (all targets/mixed targets (clustered)/mixed targets (split)/no target) and Age (1-year bins for children and adults as a whole): Correct/maximal (1/0) ~ Sentence Type + Object Type +  Age + (1|Subject).

First of all, we will predict the pattern of responses between adults and children in critical and control trials (i.e. trials with PDDs vs. all or some): Correct/maximal (1/0) ~ Sentence Type*Age + Object Type + (1|Subject).

Based on results from previous studies , there should be an interaction effect between Sentence Type and Age on the pattern of responses. This interaction would indicate that there is no difference among adults and children for controls, but that there is one for critical trials. The difference between critical and control trials will also be explored via Wilcoxon non-parametric test.

One exception where adults and children may perform differently in a control is where a sentence with some is presented with the all-target object type. Because the sentence does not conform to the so-called ‘some-but-not-all’ scalar implicature, adults should judge the sentence as false (i.e. choose the silly character). In contrast, it is widely attested that children fail to compute the scalar implicature, and thus they are likely to accept the sentence in such a setting (i.e. choose the smart character).

We will then focus on the performance in the critical trials where target objects are mixed with non-target objects. Proportion of non-maximal responses (i.e. choosing the smart character in such trials) will be predicted from Age, and the effect of Age will be interpreted as evidence that children are more likely to interpret PDDs non-maximally relative to adults. 
The contextual effect on the interpretation of PDDs will be examined by comparing the proportion of non-maximal responses between the two mixed object types (clustered vs. split): Maximal (1/0) ~ Object Type*Age + Sentence Type + (1|Subject).

If the visual contiguity of target objects triggers the non-maximal interpretation (in line with Schwartz 2012), there should be the main effect of Object Type.

If children are more prone to the contextual manipulation than adults, which is the primary hypothesis of this study, there should be an interaction between Age and Object Type such that children’s non-maximal responses increase for the clustered object type to a greater extent than those of adults.

q20.value: We may center and/or scale continuous predictors to facilitate model fit.

q21.value: All the tests will be two-tailed, with p = .05 significance level.

q22.value: In addition to the exclusion criteria noted in Section 9.3 (providing incorrect answers to at least 6 out of 8 unambiguously true/false trials), children’s data will be discarded if they are not able to understand the training trials after three attempts.

q23.value: If a subject provides less than 6 responses out of 8 critical trials, we will code the missing responses as N/A and exclude them (along with the subject) from our analyses.

q24.value: For adult subjects, we will conduct the experiment in two different settings (online and on-site, though the latter might not be conducted due to the COVID-19 pandemic). One reason for conducting the pilot study online is to replicate the study by Schwartz (2012), who reports the possibility of non-maximal interpretation of PDDs among adults. However, because of the communicative nature of the present study (i.e. listening to the puppet and giving them a reward), we would like to shift to testing subjects in a laboratory setting. Therefore, while the results of the online and on-site experiments should be comparable if Schwartz’s study is replicated, they will be analyzed for any unexpected differences.

registration_responses.q1: Examination of domain restriction effects on the interpretation of plural definite descriptions
registration_responses.q3:
Developmental literature suggests that children often exhibit the non-maximal interpretation of plural definite descriptions (PDDs). The cause of such an interpretation has been attributed to the initial association of PDDs with plurality but not maximality (Karmiloff-Smith 1979), and the lack of mapping of linguistic structure to the associated concepts (Caponigro et al. 2012). Furthermore, Schwartz (2012) argues that while the maximal interpretation is the default for PDDs, adult English speakers could also interpret PDDs non-maximally when a restricted domain is applied. summary.value: Preregistration for Study 2 of SRS Calibration Project (Drummond & Fischhoff). Please see attached document.

registration_responses.summary: Preregistration for Study 2 of SRS Calibration Project (Drummond & Fischhoff). Please see attached document.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will be recruiting 300 participants with the expectation that our post-exclusion sample will be around 250 participants.

analyses.value: We will be performing a standard principal component analysis. All components whose eigenvalues are above 1 will be retained.

outliers.value:
Exclusions: Any participant who writes nonsense to an open ended question (asking them to describe the last task they just completed in just 1-2 sentences)  will have their data removed prior to analysis.

Outliers: Any score that is +/- 3 SD from the mean for any given task will be removed. Some data may need to be normalized via log transformations before this can occur.

dependent.value:
The following are all of the DVs:

Sampling: The number of times a participant draws in the beads task (every trial they didn't draw on is a greater degree of undersampling)
Unpacking: Combining the probability estimates of the Toronto Temperature and NY sports teams questions. Creates a continuous variable that goes above 100% (for every % above 100% the more that person fails to unpack alternative)
Missing Info: The average "knownness" ratings for reasons listed for the three questions (higher average reflects greater failure to identify missing info; For exploratory purposes can also look at # of reasons listed or dichotomoize the scale into known/ unknown)
Positive Test Strategy art task): The proportion of titles that are positive toward the predicted more popular painting and of titles that are negative toward the painting not chosen relative to all of the titles selected. (the greater the proportion the higher positive test strategy)
Positive Test Strategy causal analysis task): The ranking of the three questions about the causes of the event (the lower the ranking of the question about the known cause, the lower the positive test strategy).
Non-Diagnostic Evidence Selection one piece of info task): Total number of same piece of information for the other category choices across the problems (the higher the number the greater tendency to make non-diagnostic evidence selection)
Non-Diagnostic Evidence Selection ask/do not ask task): Scored out of 4 as: -1 if they ask the redundant question, and -1 for every question they didn't ask that they should have.

conditions.value: All participants will be in the same condition

hypothesis.value: This is an observational study where we are testing the relation between tasks in stage 1 of our belief process battery. The purpose of the study is to see how many components performance on these tasks load onto and whether we can remove redundant items from this state of the battery.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Belief Process Battery Stage 1 (W20)
registration_responses.sample: We will be recruiting 300 participants with the expectation that our post-exclusion sample will be around 250 participants.

Exclusions: Any participant who writes nonsense to an open ended question (asking them to describe the last task they just completed in just 1-2 sentences)  will have their data removed prior to analysis.

Outliers: Any score that is +/- 3 SD from the mean for any given task will be removed. Some data may need to be normalized via log transformations before this can occur.

Positive Test Strategy art task): The proportion of titles that are positive toward the predicted more popular painting and of titles that are negative toward the painting not chosen relative to all of the titles selected. (the greater the proportion the higher positive test strategy)
Positive Test Strategy causal analysis task): The ranking of the three questions about the causes of the event (the lower the ranking of the question about the known cause, the lower the positive test strategy).
Non-Diagnostic Evidence Selection one piece of info task): Total number of same piece of information for the other category choices across the problems (the higher the number the greater tendency to make non-diagnostic evidence selection)
Non-Diagnostic Evidence Selection ask/do not ask task): Scored out of 4 as: -1 if they ask the redundant question, and -1 for every question they didn't ask that they should have.
registration_responses.conditions: All participants will be in the same condition
registration_responses.hypothesis: This is an observational study where we are testing the relation between tasks in stage 1 of our belief process battery. The purpose of the study is to see how many components performance on these tasks load onto and whether we can remove redundant items from this state of the battery.

q3.value:
This study examines whether people take credit for policy changes and feel licensed to make potentially dubious decisions that counteract intended policy objectives. 

The central argument is that there is “moral” cost that constrains managers from dismissing employees. Increasing unemployment insurance, which alleviates the economic hardship of displaced employees, reduces moral cost and induces managers to fire marginal employees. The focus on “moral cost” extends prior labor economics and management research that has focused singularly on the financial costs to employee dismissals as well as research on unemployment insurance that focuses on employees’ search behavior while neglecting its effects on a firm’s decision to fire.

q4.value: I plan to conduct simple survey-based experiments, first informing participants of actual and hypothetical policy changes with varying degrees of details (e.g., there was recently an increase in unemployment insurance) and ask participants to make a series of related hypothetical decisions (e.g., rate on a scale of 1 to 7 how easy it should be for firms to layoff workers). The in-going hypothesis is that participants informed of recent hikes in unemployment insurance will be more support of a flexible dismissal policy, partially mediated by their response to the question: “What is the level of economic difficulty following involuntary unemployment?”

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between subjects design 
UI: 4 conditions (no information UI, information on UI, increase in UI, decrease in UI)

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through MTurk. Participants will be paid $0.50 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 per condition (4 conditions total). We will attempt to recruit up to 120, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

question.value:
We manipulate the direction and intensity of policy changes, in particular unemployment insurance and minimum wage

a (control). In 2019, most states remain similar in the rate of labor participation rate.
b. In 2019, most states provide unemployment insurance of 12 weeks. 
c. In 2019, most states increased unemployment insurance by 30% from 12 weeks to 16 weeks.
d. In 2019, most states reduced unemployment insurance by 30% from 16 weeks to 12 weeks.

What is the level of economic difficulty following involuntary unemployment?
1. Very low                                7. Very high

How difficult should it be for firms to layoff workers? (4=Current level)
1. Very easy                             7. Very difficult

How difficult should it be for firms with declining sales to layoff workers? (4=Current level)
1. Very easy                             7. Very difficult

Do you think U.S. workers are treated fairly? (4=Global average)
1. Unfairly                                 7. Fairly

How likely would you consider donating to the nonprofit WRPI (Worker Retraining and Placement Institute)?
1. Very unlikely                        7. Very likely
ANOVA

q21.value:
Two tailed tests
Multiple conditions (increase in UI vs. decrease in UI)

q22.value:
I will be using comprehension checks (those who do not accurately answer the following question)

How long is the average unemployment insurance?  1. Don’t know   2. 12  weeks 3. 14 weeks 4. 16 weeks

q23.value: if a subject does not complete any of the survey questions, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to taste preferences. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, income, and marital status) and the primary outcome measures of taste preferences.

attributes.title: Rejection sensitivity and Wise Reasoning in China

summary.value:
In this study, we examine the relationship between rejection sensitivity (RS) and wise reasoning (WR) about a workplace conflict among a non-western sample in mainland China. 
Following previous studies with North American participants where we found that higher sensitivity to rejection predicts lower wise reasoning concerning a social conflict in the workplace, we test whether this relationship also manifests in a non-western culture.
This project contains one document (Method and analytical plan_Chinese sample.docx) for pre-registration describing the method, exclusion criteria, and analytical plan for the study.

registration_responses.summary:
In this study, we examine the relationship between rejection sensitivity (RS) and wise reasoning (WR) about a workplace conflict among a non-western sample in mainland China. 
Following previous studies with North American participants where we found that higher sensitivity to rejection predicts lower wise reasoning concerning a social conflict in the workplace, we test whether this relationship also manifests in a non-western culture.
This project contains one document (Method and analytical plan_Chinese sample.docx) for pre-registration describing the method, exclusion criteria, and analytical plan for the study.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Car-wash EXPERIMENT - 0 VS. 1 PRICE

Participants will read a scenario in which they are driving their car. They have a coupon for a free (1 NIS) exterior cleaning. They see a car wash where they may redeem the coupon and decide to get the exterior cleaning ("basic service"). While getting the "basic service", they see a sign about an interior cleaning ("premium service") for which they can "pay as much as you decide". Participants are asked to indicate the amount they would be willing to pay for the additional premium service.

other.value:
We also collect responses regarding participants' perceptions of the basic service's quality. We will compare the zero and low price conditions to examine whether one of the services is perceived to be of a higher quality than the other.
We will also use the quality rating at a covariate in the model when predicting willingness to pay.

sample.value: Based on the sample size in our previous experiments, we aim to collect 200 valid responses.

analyses.value: We will fit a multiple regression model, predicting premium-service price from condition (zero vs. 1). We will test model robustness by controlling for participants' beliefs about the real-world full price of the basic service (external car wash), participants' beliefs about the full price of the premium service (interior wash), whether the participant owns a car, and controlling for demographic variables (gender, age).

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants if they
1. do not complete the study.
2. do not pass attention check/quality item (indicating the price of the external service in the scenario).
3. indicate external or interior car-wash prices greater than 3SD from the mean.

dependent.value: Amount indicated for the premium service (i.e., an interior car cleaning) in Israeli Shekels.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to 1 of 2 between-subjects conditions:
1. zero price
2. low price (1 NIS)

hypothesis.value:
In this study, we examine whether a zero price service (free external car wash service) vs. low price service (1 NIS external car wash service, ~$0.25 USD) would lead to lower willingness to pay for an additional premium service (an interior car cleaning)

We predict that participants in the zero price condition will indicate significantly lower amounts for the premium service compared to participants in the very low price condition, above and beyond the negligible difference in prices between the experimental conditions (difference of 1 NIS).

summary.value:
In this study, we assess participants' wise reasoning about a work-related difficult social situation using SWiS (21 items, Brienza et al., 2018) and their rejection sensitivity (RSQ-A, Berenson et al., 2009) 3 times during a 10-day period. 
The method and hypotheses are described in the attached file. 
The exclusion criteria and analytical plan are outlined in the attached file.

registration_responses.summary:
In this study, we assess participants' wise reasoning about a work-related difficult social situation using SWiS (21 items, Brienza et al., 2018) and their rejection sensitivity (RSQ-A, Berenson et al., 2009) 3 times during a 10-day period. 
The method and hypotheses are described in the attached file. 
The exclusion criteria and analytical plan are outlined in the attached file.

attributes.title: The relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery from overshadowing in associative learning

q1.value: The relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery from overshadowing in associative learning

q3.value: Obsessive-compulsive disorder(OCD)is characterized by impulsivity and disinhibition. Patients with OCD are impaired in the suppression of irrelevant memories during competitive recall(Demeter et al., 2014). We had examined exploratory the relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery of overshadowing in associative learning on the MTurk sample in study 1. We found that the obsessive-compulsive tendency negatively correlated with the causality rating on recovery from overshadowing and did not correlate with the rating on overshadowing. We conduct the replication study about the relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery of overshadowing in the Japanese sample.

q4.value:
1.	The obsessive-compulsive tendency negatively correlates with the causality rating on recovery from overshadowing.
2.	The obsessive-compulsive tendency does not correlate with the causality rating on overshadowing.
3.	The obsessive-compulsive tendency negatively correlates with the causality rating on the acquisition.
4.	The obsessive-compulsive tendency positively correlates with the causality rating on control.
These hypotheses are based on our study 1.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study is a cross-sectional observation study (online survey).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the Japanese crowdsourcing services. Participants will be paid ¥470 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 20 years old and a native Japanese speaker.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 350 participants. We expect approximately 20% dropout or unusable data. So, we will attempt to recruit 438 participants at least, assuming dropout or unusable data.

q14.value:
A power analysis was conducted using the pwr(1.2-2) package. Our goal was to obtain 0.90 power to detect a correlation coefficient of 0.20 at the 0.0125 alpha error probability. The correlation coefficient of 0.20 is the smallest value of the correlation coefficient hypotheses 1, 3, and 4 in study 1. We set the significance level is 0.05 and applied Bonferroni corrections that 0.05 is divided by the number of testing hypotheses. We need 350 participants to obtain statistical power at the 0.90 level, with an alpha error probability of 0.0125. We also expect approximately 20% dropout or unusable data. Finally, we will attempt to recruit up to 438, assuming dropout or unusable data. The R code is as bellow.

sample_size <- pwr.r.test(n = NULL, 
                          r = 0.20, 
                          sig.level = 0.0125, 
                          power = 0.90, 
                          alternative = c("two.sided"))
sample_size$n/0.8

question.value:
Primary outcomes
These outcomes will use in confirmatory analyses to examine four hypotheses.
1.	The causality rating on the recovery from overshadowing, overshadowing, acquisition and control: We set four conditions (recovery from overshadowing, overshadowing, acquisition and control) within participants. We will ask participants to see the pair of food and allergic reaction of patients on each condition. Then, we will measure the causality rating of food and allergic reaction on each condition by asking participants “Please indicate how likely it is that eating this food item will cause an allergic reaction in the patient”(on a scale of 0-9, from “0 An allergic reaction is not likely” to “9 An allergic reaction is likely”).
2.	The Japanese version of the Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory

Secondary outcomes
These outcomes will use in exploratory analyses.
1.	The confidence rating on the recovery from overshadowing, overshadowing, acquisition and control: We also measure the confidence rating of food and allergic reaction on each condition by asking participants “How confident are you about your decisions?”(on a scale of 0-9, from “0 not completely confident” to “9 An allergic reaction is likely”).
2.	The Short Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale
3.	Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7

We will use the total score of the Japanese version of the Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory, the Short Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale and Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 by summing rating on each item.

We will conduct the correlation analysis using Pearson’s r to examine the below association. If the outcome will not follow a normal distribution, we use Kendall’s tau.
1.	The association between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the causality rating on recovery from overshadowing.
2.	The association between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the causality rating on overshadowing.
3.	The association between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the causality rating on the acquisition.
4.	The association between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the causality rating on control.

q22.value: We will exclude the participants with some severe health problems that affect the results and the participants that participate more than twice.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete the survey, that participant will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We will conduct the exploratory analysis to generate hypotheses using secondary outcomes.

We had examined exploratory the relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery of overshadowing in associative learning on the MTurk sample in study 1. We found that the obsessive-compulsive tendency negatively correlated with the causality rating on recovery from overshadowing and did not correlate with the rating on overshadowing. We conduct the replication study about the relationship between the obsessive-compulsive tendency and the recovery of overshadowing in the Japanese sample.

1.	The obsessive-compulsive tendency negatively correlates with the causality rating on recovery from overshadowing.

These hypotheses are based on our study 1.

attributes.title: Note regarding the method/analysis
attributes.description: We eventually decided not to include the two-items measuring explicit support for diversity since those might not have a clear pattern of effect (after the human rights threat manipulation more right wingers might want it more, but more left wingers might want it less). So for this measure we would actually predict an interaction. To keep with our original hypothesis we decided to not include this measure and only keep the DV measuring distributions of right vs. left wingers, expecting that our manipulation would increase preference for left wingers in the population and Knesset.

q1.value: Group survival and the perceived importance of political diversity (minority rights threat) - Revised materials

q2.value: Uri Lifshin, Gilad Hirschberger, Michal Reifen Tagar, Tali Aloni

q3.value:
The purpose of this research was to test the hypothesis that beyond peoples' personal political views, they realize the importance of heterogeneity in political views as a means of promoting group survival.

In the earlier experiments people with different political views did in fact prefer political diversity/ heterogeneity in their group.
Under conditions of threat of war participants preferred a relatively larger percent of right-wing individuals compared to conditions that implied that there is an opportunity for peace – beyond their personal political beliefs.

We then conducted another study to test if people would prefer more left wingers to deal with other topics, such as threats to minorities, promotion of tolerance in society. We indeed found support for that. 

The goal of the current study was to test if making the issue of the importance of tolerance towards others in society salient would cause people to prefer that there would be more left wingers in society and in the government, compared to a control condition in which issues with public transportation in Israel will be salient 

In the current study participants will be randomly assigned to complete a short manipulation where they are asked to think about either what needs to be done to increase tolerance towards others or about what needs to be done to improve national security in their country. Another group will get none of these questions. 

After this brief manipulation participants will answer a set of question regarding the topic (how important it is to them) followed by questions about what percentage of people in the political left and right would be optimal for Israel. They will also write what they think is positive about both political parties. We will also add a variable asking for their explicit support for political heterogeneity in their country.

Personal political view will be measured at the end of the study and will be used as a covarite. 

Participants will then be debriefed about the purpose of the study.

q4.value:
Our hypothesis is that while participants who read that participants who would think about the need for more Tolerance in their country would prefer more left-wing people in the public and government – regardless of the own participant’s political views.  
Participants who would think about needs for national security would prefer more right wingers compared to the other conditions. 

We will probe for interactions with political view, but generally expect a main effect beyond political view (using political view as a covariate).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: 3 groups. We will also test for interactions with political view -- either as a continuous variable, and also when its categorized into left wing, right wing and center. Again our hypotheses is of a main effect

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions using Qualtirics' auto randomization function.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will conduct a study online on Reddit (on Rsample size as well as non-partisan political subreddits and subreddits of countries that will also positing the study) . Here we will ask participants to state what country they are from. 
Participants who report not completing the study in 1 time or having difficulties will be excluded. 
Participants who will not write anything related to the question in the open ended manipulation will be removed
Participants with missing data on critical variables will be excluded. 
Participant who reported not completing the study seriously (over 5 on a 9 point scale will be excluded
Participants who take  too little time to complete the study (the study is short so we will have to see what the average time is, but generally it should take more than 30 seconds online minute. 
duplicate IP addresses  will be removed 

For the within country analysis, we will remove participants who reported currently living in a different country from their home country.

q13.value:
We will try to collect data from 250 participants 

In the reddit sample we are limited to how many times we can post the study in many subreddits (aside from rsamplesize) so we will have to see if the study gets attention or not. We will aim for a total sample of at least 250 participants. But if we can we will try to get more.

q14.value: Power analysis (a-priori, F family) indicated that to find a medium-small effect (partial eta squared of ,04) effect at 80% power with 3 groups in an ANCOVA we will 235 participants.

q15.value:
In the Reddit sample we may want to collect data from as many people as we can, since they may be of different nationalities, and this can increase the chance that we get close to the needed sample size in various countries. Again we can use a basic international sample - as our previous studies showed relative generalization of the effects,  but if we can we would want to have a bigger sample. 
On the other had we can get 0 or very few responses from various countries - in case that our post would not get attention.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to think about what needs to be done to improve either - Tolerance towards others
- National security
- no question (control)

We have 1 dependent variable (1-item) pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in the public and  1 dependent variable (1-item)  pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in  government in their country.

We also have a few questions about the importance of the topic. These are meant to  Specifically the item that measure how important the topic is to the participant personally and to Israel in general.  We will also check if these are correlated to preference of right / left wingers within each condition (it should be correlated more with left wingers in the Tolerance condition, but more with right wingers in the Security condition). 

We will also include an open ended question about the positive things about left/ right wingers  (these will be coded for themes). We expect that more mentioning of left wingers' care for minority rights and tolerance (we are expecting this to be a theme) would be mentioned - and we will also test if these mentions were grater in tolerance condition.

To examine our hypothesis reg the 2 items measuring preferences for political diversity we will first run a MANCOVA anlysis (to reduce the chance for type 1 error), and then also look at the univariate level for each of the 2 items.

As mentioned, we will run a MANCOVA (controlling for political view). But first we will also prob for interactions (looking at political view both as a continuous variable and as a categorized variable of 3 levels). If the interaction is sig, we will report that analysis rather than the MANCOVA/ANCOVA. If its not then political view would only be used as a covariate. We will also examine if religiosity is a sig covariate or not. 

NOTE THAT IN THE REDDIT STUDY WE WILL NOT CENTER THE POLITICAL ATTITUDE VARIABLE BUT RATHER USED EXPLICIT CATEGORIES TO PREVENT MISREPRESENTATION OF THE POLITICAL VIEW.

q20.value: We have a coding scheme for the categorical variables based on previous research.

q21.value: Sig effects are at 95% confidence (p < .05). We have a directional hypothesis so for us p < 05 on a 1 tailed test would be considered statistically significant (or marginally statistically significant)

q22.value:
In the Israeli field study Participants who wont complete the materials properly (i.e., alone, in the right order, not being on the phone etc) will be excluded. 
Non-Jews will be excluded (since this affects political views in Israel). 
Participants who will not write anything related to the question in the open ended manipulation will be removed
Participants with missing data on critical variables will be excluded.

registration_responses.q1: Group survival and the perceived importance of political diversity (minority rights threat) - Revised materials
registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of this research was to test the hypothesis that beyond peoples' personal political views, they realize the importance of heterogeneity in political views as a means of promoting group survival.

In the earlier experiments people with different political views did in fact prefer political diversity/ heterogeneity in their group.
Under conditions of threat of war participants preferred a relatively larger percent of right-wing individuals compared to conditions that implied that there is an opportunity for peace – beyond their personal political beliefs.

We then conducted another study to test if people would prefer more left wingers to deal with other topics, such as threats to minorities, promotion of tolerance in society. We indeed found support for that. 

The goal of the current study was to test if making the issue of the importance of tolerance towards others in society salient would cause people to prefer that there would be more left wingers in society and in the government, compared to a control condition in which issues with public transportation in Israel will be salient 

In the current study participants will be randomly assigned to complete a short manipulation where they are asked to think about either what needs to be done to increase tolerance towards others or about what needs to be done to improve national security in their country. Another group will get none of these questions. 

After this brief manipulation participants will answer a set of question regarding the topic (how important it is to them) followed by questions about what percentage of people in the political left and right would be optimal for Israel. They will also write what they think is positive about both political parties. We will also add a variable asking for their explicit support for political heterogeneity in their country.

Personal political view will be measured at the end of the study and will be used as a covarite. 

Participants will then be debriefed about the purpose of the study.
registration_responses.q4:
Our hypothesis is that while participants who read that participants who would think about the need for more Tolerance in their country would prefer more left-wing people in the public and government – regardless of the own participant’s political views.  
Participants who would think about needs for national security would prefer more right wingers compared to the other conditions. 

We will probe for interactions with political view, but generally expect a main effect beyond political view (using political view as a covariate).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions using Qualtirics' auto randomization function.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
We will try to collect data from 250 participants 

In the reddit sample we are limited to how many times we can post the study in many subreddits (aside from rsamplesize) so we will have to see if the study gets attention or not. We will aim for a total sample of at least 250 participants. But if we can we will try to get more.
registration_responses.q14: Power analysis (a-priori, F family) indicated that to find a medium-small effect (partial eta squared of ,04) effect at 80% power with 3 groups in an ANCOVA we will 235 participants.
registration_responses.q15:
In the Reddit sample we may want to collect data from as many people as we can, since they may be of different nationalities, and this can increase the chance that we get close to the needed sample size in various countries. Again we can use a basic international sample - as our previous studies showed relative generalization of the effects,  but if we can we would want to have a bigger sample. 
On the other had we can get 0 or very few responses from various countries - in case that our post would not get attention.
registration_responses.q20: We have a coding scheme for the categorical variables based on previous research.
registration_responses.q21: Sig effects are at 95% confidence (p < .05). We have a directional hypothesis so for us p < 05 on a 1 tailed test would be considered statistically significant (or marginally statistically significant)

registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants will be randomly assigned to think about what needs to be done to improve either - Tolerance towards others
- National security
- no question (control)
registration_responses.q17.question:
We have 1 dependent variable (1-item) pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in the public and  1 dependent variable (1-item)  pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in  government in their country.

We also have a few questions about the importance of the topic. These are meant to  Specifically the item that measure how important the topic is to the participant personally and to Israel in general.  We will also check if these are correlated to preference of right / left wingers within each condition (it should be correlated more with left wingers in the Tolerance condition, but more with right wingers in the Security condition). 

We will also include an open ended question about the positive things about left/ right wingers  (these will be coded for themes). We expect that more mentioning of left wingers' care for minority rights and tolerance (we are expecting this to be a theme) would be mentioned - and we will also test if these mentions were grater in tolerance condition.
registration_responses.q18.question: To examine our hypothesis reg the 2 items measuring preferences for political diversity we will first run a MANCOVA anlysis (to reduce the chance for type 1 error), and then also look at the univariate level for each of the 2 items.
registration_responses.q19.question:
As mentioned, we will run a MANCOVA (controlling for political view). But first we will also prob for interactions (looking at political view both as a continuous variable and as a categorized variable of 3 levels). If the interaction is sig, we will report that analysis rather than the MANCOVA/ANCOVA. If its not then political view would only be used as a covariate. We will also examine if religiosity is a sig covariate or not. 

NOTE THAT IN THE REDDIT STUDY WE WILL NOT CENTER THE POLITICAL ATTITUDE VARIABLE BUT RATHER USED EXPLICIT CATEGORIES TO PREVENT MISREPRESENTATION OF THE POLITICAL VIEW.
